Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/19/23, during an outing, staff member took 3 youth to the
store. The youth stole alcohol and drank it in the bathroom. Staff
member became aware and took the youth to McDonalds
afterwards to mask the smell of alcohol in attempt to hide what
occurred from other staff upon return.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 23, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth A reported on February 19, 2023, he went to Meijer with
Youth B, Youth C, and Staff 1. He reported when they walked into
the store, the youth walked ahead of Staff 1 which gave Youth A
the ability to steal two mini shot bottles of alcohol from the front of
the store. Youth A reported Youth C then got out of the eyesight of
Staff 1 and stole a bottle of alcohol and brought it into the
bathroom. When Youth C came of out the bathroom, Youth A and
Youth B went in there to drink from the bottle. He reported Staff 1
was not in the bathroom with the youth. He reported they both
drank from the bottle and Youth B poured the rest of the bottle
down the toilet. When they got into the van, the youth drank some
of their energy drink and put the mini shot bottle he stole into the
energy drink and Youth A threw the bottle outside the window.
During this time, Staff 1 was driving the vehicle to McDonald’s
because he wanted a drink. Youth A stated while driving Staff 1
said it smelled like alcohol in the vehicle. Staff 1 drove through the
2

drive-thru at McDonald’s and got himself a drink and Youth B
wanted french fries. When they arrived back at the unit, they just
went on with normal programming. Upon returning to the facility,
he reported he did sneak two mini bottles of alcohol into his
bedroom and reported not being checked by staff. He reported it is
a fifty/fifty chance that you will be checked over by staff when
entering back onto the unit. Youth A reported staff found his two
alcohol bottles and a cell phone he brought back from a home
pass when they completed a room search. He reported staff only
do room searches where there is a concern. Youth A reported,
Supervisor received a call from Meijer stating they saw the youth
steal alcohol and that was why room searches were completed.
Youth A reported on the outing, Staff 1 supervised the best he
could since all the youth were going in different directions in the
store. He reported they would have done this with any staff that
had taken them on an outing. Youth A is unaware if Staff 1 knew
they were drinking or not.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 23, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
When Youth B met with this consultant and MDHHS worker, the
first thing he asked was if Staff 1 was in trouble and going to get
fired. Youth B was asked why he was concerned, and he reported
that on February 19, 2023, on an outing with Staff 1 to Meijer, he
and two other youths stole alcohol. Youth B was asked to explain
what happened on that outing. He explained they picked up Youth
A from a home visit with Youth C and Staff 1. Youth C asked on
the way back if they could go to Meijer and Staff 1 agreed they
could go on an outing. Youth B reported Youth A and Youth C
said to him on the way there they were going to steal some
alcohol. He reported when they arrived at Meijer the three youth
walked in front of Staff 1 which gave them the ability to take a
couple of the small alcohol shot bottles at the front of the store.
While in Meijer all three youth went their separate ways to look for
a nonalcoholic drink to purchase and Staff 1 redirected them by
stating “whatever you have, put it back so I don’t get in trouble.”
Youth B reported he looked over at the books with Staff 1 and that
was when Youth C snuck off to steal the alcohol bottle. He
reported Youth C then asked to use the restroom that was near
where Staff 1 and Youth B were looking at books. Youth B stated
when Youth C came out of the restroom, Youth A, Youth B, and
Staff 1 went into the restroom. Staff 1 then left the restroom with
Youth A and Youth B in there. He reported that was when they
found the bottle of alcohol Youth C hid in there and they drank
from it. He reported once they left the store the youth drank some
of their energy drink in the vehicle and then put the mini shot
3

bottle, they stole into the can to drink from it. Youth B reported
Staff 1 said in the vehicle that it smelled like alcohol. He reported
they went to McDonald’s next but was not sure whose idea it was,
and he reported he threw out the energy drink and the empty mini
shot bottle there. When they got back to the unit, Youth A brought
in two more mini shot bottles, and they were not checked when
entering the unit. He reported staff is supposed to do pocket
checks when a youth returns to the facility after an outing. Youth B
reported the next day Youth A reported not feeling well, so Youth
B told Staff 2 about the alcohol they drank because he was
concerned about Youth A. He reported when youth go on outings
to a store they need to stay in the eyesight of staff and he reported
Staff 1 did a decent job, they were just sneaky.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 23, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth C reported on February 19, 2023, he went to Meijer with
Youth A, Youth B, and Staff 1. He reported while walking through
the store at one point the youth split up a little bit while Staff 1 was
walking behind them. Youth C reported he ran around the corner
and grabbed a fifth of alcohol and hid it in his jacket. He reported
Staff 1 then redirected the youth to stay together and asked Youth
C specifically if he had anything. Youth C told Staff 1 no and then
asked to use the bathroom. Staff 1 allowed Youth C to use the
bathroom since it was in visual sight of where the other youth
were. Youth C reported he brought the bottle into the bathroom
and then told the other youth it was in there when he left. He
reported the other two youth then used the bathroom and drank
from the bottle. Youth C reported at that time Staff 1 was outside
the bathroom when the drinking occurred. When the three youth
were heading to the checkout lines to buy their approved drinks,
they stole a couple of the mini shot bottles of alcohol that was
upfront by the checkout line. Youth C reported at that time Staff 1
was walking behind the youth as they were heading to the
checkout line and did not see them. He reported when they went
into the van, Youth A and Youth B put the mini shot bottles of
alcohol into the energy drinks they bought. Youth C reported Staff
1 was driving during the time this was occurring and reported he
does not believe Staff 1 knew what was going on. He reported the
only way Staff 1 might have known was because Youth B was
talking about alcohol in the car. Youth C reported Staff 1 took
them to McDonald’s because Staff 1 wanted a drink, and another
youth got french fries. There were no reports of Staff 1 taking the
youth to McDonald’s to help cover up the alcohol. Youth C
reported Staff 1 does a good job at supervision and the three
youth were just sneaky. He reported he would have done the
4

same thing with any other staff because he just wanted to get a bit
of a buzz from alcohol.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 1,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported on
February 19, 2023, he took Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C to
Meijer after picking up Youth A from a home visit. He reported the
youth were the ones that asked to go to Meijer to get snacks and
a plan was determined it was going to be a quick trip. Staff 1
reported when they arrived at Meijer, the three youth were walking
in front of him, and he was texting his cousin about his financial
situation. Staff 1 admitted the youth were further away than they
should have been, and he did not have full supervision of the
youth. He reported when he caught up to Youth C, he was in the
alcohol aisle and told him to get out of there and asked him if he
had anything. Staff 1 reported Youth C told him he didn’t have
anything and then he asked where the other two youth were.
Youth A and Youth B were over by the soft drink aisle. Once the
youth picked out their drinks, Youth B asked Staff 1 if they could
look at the electronics. When at the electronics area, Youth A
asked to use the bathroom which Staff 1 allowed since it was in
eyesight. Staff 1 reported he had a conversation with Youth C
about tv shows and video games. When Staff 1 looked up from
that conversation, he noticed Youth B was gone and went to
search the bathroom. When he arrived in the bathroom, Youth A
was walking out of the bathroom stale and Youth B was walking
into one. Staff 1 reported he was concerned that Youth A and
Youth B were in the bathroom alone because there have been
rumors that those two youth are in a relationship and concerned,
they were being sexually inappropriate with one another. When
asked what the bathroom policy is on community outings, Staff 1
reported if there is one youth needing to go then they can go while
the area remains in the eyesight of staff. If two youth need to go
and it is a bathroom with multiple stalls, staff are supposed to go
in so there are no concerns within the bathroom. Staff 1 denied
ever seeing Youth C go into the bathroom. After the youths were
done with the bathroom, they headed back to the vehicle and
Youth A asked to stop at McDonald’s for french fires. Staff 1
stopped at McDonald’s drive-thru on the way back to the facility.
Staff 1 reported he had no concerns about the alcohol use of the
youth. He believed he was being interviewed because of concerns
about Youth A and Youth B being in the bathroom alone with one
another and something sexually happening. When it was
disclosed to Staff 1 about the reported alcohol use on the outing,
he became very emotional and reported he was shocked this
occurred. Staff 1 reported he had trust in the youth and cannot
5

believe they did this. He reported he knows he is in the wrong
because he did not follow the supervision as he lost sight of the
youth when getting into Meijer and not knowing that Youth B went
into the bathroom while Youth A was in there. Staff 1 reported he
did not complete pocket checks on Youth A, Youth B, or Youth C
after their outing to Meijer on February 19, 2023. He reported he
knows that he was supposed to complete pocket checks of the
youth because they are not supposed to bring any items onto the
unit without staff knowing. Staff 1 reported he did not complete
pocket checks because he made a promise to another unit to
watch an all-star game on TV with him and did not want to miss it.
Staff 1 denied he was aware that Youth A had snuck mini bottles
of alcohol into his bedroom from that outing.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
23, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported
on February 20, 2023, he took Youth B on an outing to Meijer to
buy a new chair for the unit. He reported Youth B disclosed to him
on an outing on February 19, 2023, to Meijer, Youth C stole
alcohol and himself and Youth A drank the alcohol. Youth B
reported the youth also stole a couple of shot bottles of alcohol
and mixed it in their energy drinks. He also reported Youth A
brought some mini shot bottles back into the unit. Youth B
reported Staff 1 knew they were drinking and took them to
McDonald’s to help get the smell off their breath so Staff 1 would
not get in trouble. Staff 1 told the youth that “If I get caught, I will
get fired.” Youth B reported to Staff 2 that Staff 1 just let the youth
walk in the aisle and was not fully supervising the youth. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 has had coaching on not fully paying attention to
the youth on the unit. Staff 2 reported on outings, youth are
supposed to all stay together and be in the eyesight of staff. If a
youth needs to go to the bathroom, then all go into the bathroom
location if there are multiple stalls or stand outside of the individual
bathroom doors and take turns. Staff 2 reported before a youth is
to enter back on the unit, staff that took the youth off the unit are
supposed to do a check of the youth to make sure nothing is being
brought into the unit that they should not have.
Supervisor/ Reporting Source was interviewed via phone on
March 13, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported on February 20, 2023, Staff 2 informed her of
Youth B’s disclosure. She reported she spoke with both Youth A
and Youth B who reported they stole alcohol from Meijer and
drank alcohol within Meijer’s bathroom. Both youth disclosed Staff
1 found out they were drinking and tried to cover up the alcohol
smell by going to McDonald's. Supervisor reported she completed
6

a room search and Youth A handed her two mini alcohol bottles
and a cell phone. Youth A told Supervisor that staff did not check
in his items from his home visit or complete a pocket check after
going to the store and that was how he could sneak the items.
Supervisor reported all staff are trained that pocket checks need
to be completed on the youth when they re-enter or leave the unit,
so items are not taken out or brought back onto the unit. When a
youth goes on an overnight stay, staff need to go through the
youth’s personal items to make sure no contraband is being
brought in. Supervisor reported the policy for supervision when
staff take youth off campus is the youth are supposed to always
remain in eyesight. She also explained the bathroom policy as
stated in the Wedgwood Safety Procedure.
Shift Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
March 20, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker via
phone. Shift Supervisor reported his role at the facility is to assist
with making sure the shift runs smoothly and does not have direct
supervision over the staff members. He reported on February 19,
2023, Staff 1 was tasked to pick up Youth A from a home visit.
Youth B and Youth C went along with him for the drive and the
plan was for them to pick up Youth A and stop at a drive-through
for dinner since they may be missing dinner at the unit. Shift
Supervisor reported there was no safety plan in place for any of
the youth that was involved. He stated staff is reminded to make
sure boundaries are always appropriate with the youth but there
was no sexualized safety plan between Youth A and Youth B at
the time. Shift Supervisor reported due to the youth doing well on
the unit they were allowed to go on the outing. He reported there
was never any communication about them stopping at Meijer
before returning home. Shift Supervisor reported he did not hear
any concerns when the youth returned and Staff 1 and the youth
showed no concerning behaviors. He reported he believed Staff 1
completed the pocket checks and Youth A’s bag check before the
youth returning on the unit. Shift Supervisor reported it is the rule
that no youth is to bring in or take out items onto the unit without
being checked due to concerns of contraband. When asked what
the policy is for supervision of the unit on an outing, Shift
Supervisor reported the youth should remain in eyesight at all
times.
Documents Reviewed:
- Wedgwood Internal Incident Report number 32194
dated February 20, 2023- This incident report was
completed by Staff 2 about the disclosure from Youth B
7

about alcohol use. This incident report was consistent with
the interview completed with Staff 2.
- Wedgwood Internal Incident Report number 32196
dated February 20, 2023- This incident report was
completed by Supervisor about the alcohol bottles found in
Youth A’s bedroom. Youth A disclosed to Supervisor about
the incident of stealing it and that Staff 1 was aware of the
incident. Youth A told Supervisor that Staff 1 took them to
McDonald’s afterward to get food to get the alcohol off their
breath before returning to the unit.
- Wedgwood Staff Radio Procedure- This procedure notes
direct care staff members are required to always maintain
line-of-sight supervision of youths except when youth are in
their individual sleeping rooms or bathrooms.
- Wedgwood Client Safety Procedure- This procedure
notes if clients enter bathrooms that are used by multiple
individuals (e.g. in a public setting off campus), staff
members should accompany clients into the bathroom
while maintaining the client’s privacy.
- Wedgwood Client Search Procedure- This procedure
notes the requirements of staff needing to make sure youth
do not bring contraband items into the unit after being out
of the unit for a period of time. If there is a case of
suspecting that client has a contraband item, inform the
client that since they have not freely turned in the item, you
continue to suspect they have that item and that you must
conduct a search of their person, belongings, and/or living
area. This was followed when a room search was
completed of Youth A’s room.
- Human Resource File for Staff 1- Staff 1 had no
disciplinary actions noted within his HR file. Staff 1’s
training file was reviewed and noted to be up to date on all
training requirements.
- Email from Chief Administrator dated March 20, 2023-
This email indicated Staff 1 was placed on administrative
leave of absence effective 2/21/23 due to the concerns of
the allegations. The leave of absence noted the following
allegations: failure to follow activity plan as directed;
transported client to a store when this was not the plan; not
providing proper supervision while client were in the store;
after observing client in the alcohol aisle, did not perform
proper check; not providing proper supervision while client
in restroom; not providing proper supervision during client
8

purchases; not performing proper checks post purchase;
and upon return to unit did not perform proper checks, did
not inform shift supervisor of store visit. Staff 1 has
remained on administrative leave while the investigation is
being completed.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of staff following the
agency policy as it pertains to staff supervision and safety checks.
Staff 1 reported he did not have full supervision of the youth when
they were out in the community. The facility states a policy of staff
needing to have youth with eyesight while in the community. Staff
1 was aware that a pocket check should have been completed
prior to the youth entering back on the unit after a community
outing and did not complete the check. This allowed Youth A to
bring in two mini shot bottles of alcohol and cell phone into his
room.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR2022C0103001 dated 09/29/21, CAP approved 11/18/21
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff member lacks the ability to perform job duties.
Investigation During a conference call on March 29, 2023, MDHHS worker
reported there was a preponderance of evidence and Staff 1 will
have a confirmed case.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 has a confirmed
case.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
